title: Player Behavior
body: Are the PB boards to be simply an echo chamber for people coming to complain about the rules? It is apparently removable to be blunt and explain to someone that they are the problem they complain about.

replies.body:
It is fine to be blunt, but you should not be insulting in your bluntness.

>You caused this.
>
Instead of doing what a normal person would do and trying to discuss a compromise, you tried to make everyone else do your way or the highway.
>
People like you who think they know everything and that their teammates must listen to them and think the same way... you’re right, those are the problem with the League community.

There's a lot wrong here, primarily the implication that the OP is "not a normal person" (when frustration is a human emotion, and a valid one even if we don't like how it sometimes manifests in game), and the phrase "people like you who think they know everything." Additionally, there was no actual evidence that the OP caused the situation -- the OP's statement implied that they were shoving a lane, not that they were harassing the Vayne for disliking that. The OP never even *mentioned* talking to the Vayne.

In short, it feels like you assumed malevolent action and then attacked the individual. You can be blunt and direct without being condescending or insulting.

I strongly disagree that a simple statement of “normally this” implies the opposite. That is, to me, an improper conclusion that stems from reading meaning into the words other than their most common one.

Furthermore, the OP may not have caused the other player’s **actions**, but they did cause the situation. The OP would not have been frustrated in the first place had the OP not had this idea that everyone must play around them. That is the true problem here, because as I’m sure you know, a player is not going to be punished just because they don’t play the way this OP wants them to.

I think this removal is a result of trying to find a problem where one does not exist by putting the obviously unintended and very thinly reasonable meaning into the words.

Lastly, if it’s considered an insult to make a statement completely unrelated to someone (by saying what’s normal, without commenting on the other player at all), or to call out inappropriate and harmful attitudes by players in a way that, while blunt, is not insulting unless the OP chooses to be insulted by seeing their behavior discussed in a thread they posted... if this is the case, then the PB boards will simply become a place where players fear telling people the truth and the reality because “oh no, telling them they’re wrong is an insult”.

Bottom line is that if an OP is posting a thread about their actions, it is not insulting to tell the Op what a normal person would do in the situation.

> I strongly disagree that a simple statement of “normally this” implies the opposite.

That wasn't a statement of "normally this", though. You weren't saying "most players have no issue not being toxic" or anything to that effect, you basically point-blank said "You acted in a way that makes you distinctly abnormal".

> Instead of doing what a normal person would do...

It's one thing to say "most people tend to respond x way", it's another thing altogether to say "normal people would do x" and imply that they aren't a normal person.

> Lastly, if it’s considered an insult to make a statement completely unrelated to someone (by saying what’s normal, without commenting on the other player at all), or to call out inappropriate and harmful attitudes by players in a way that, while blunt, is not insulting unless the OP chooses to be insulted by seeing their behavior discussed in a thread they posted...

You made a pointed statement implying they weren't a normal person and point-blank called them a know-it-all; more specifically, "[People] who think they know everything and their teammates must listen to them..." etc., and it's pretty clear that you intended to say "You are this kind of person, and you're the problem with the League community."

So, yes, that's insulting.

> ...if this is the case, then the PB boards will simply become a place where players fear telling people the truth and the reality because “oh no, telling them they’re wrong is an insult”.

I tell people they're wrong all the time. I point out their misconceptions with the systems and I seldom mince words about it. A fair number of people, point-blank, do not know much about the behavioral systems despite their claims to understand it.

And, as with getting chat logs, getting this content removal should be a sign that perhaps you need to reevaluate how you approach discussions with other players here. There's a fine line between blunt and pointedly insulting, and I gotta agree with The Djinn; you crossed it in this case.

> Bottom line is that if an OP is posting a thread about their actions, it is not insulting to tell the Op what a normal person would do in the situation.

The bottom line is, as long as you consider a particular person abnormal, you're inevitably going to tinge your comments directed to them or about them with insults. They _are_ a normal person, and if you can't see them as such, then my best advice would just be to bow out and avoid discussion with them.

Your reply is based on your interpretations which are a stretch. I never said the person was abnormal. If that’s what you’re away from it, then I’m not sure what to do because that’s nowhere near what I said.

It seems you and The Djinn are being clouded by your own bias against the OP of that thread, thus reading my response with no insults as having insults because that’s how you *want * to interpret them.

When you have to preface things with “it’s pretty clear that” and “you basically point-blank” then those things aren’t true. Those are “escape phrases” - things your mind uses to justify to yourself that you’re correct and to try and convince others that you’re correct without actually providing any arguments.

> [{quoted}](name=rujitra,realm=NA,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=eAal50nw,comment-id=0000000000010000,timestamp=2019-11-05T23:08:16.459+0000)
>
> Your reply is based on your interpretations which are a stretch. I never said the person was abnormal. If that’s what you’re away from it, then I’m not sure what to do because that’s nowhere near what I said.

It's exactly what you said. "A normal person would have done this" directly implies that anyone who doesn't do that isn't normal. 

>It seems you and The Djinn are being clouded by your own bias against the OP of that thread, thus reading my response with no insults as having insults because that’s how you want to interpret them.

The same argument could be used in reverse to say that you're biased in favour of your own arguments, thus reading your response with insults as having no insults.
The comment was about the actions - I did not call the person abnormal.

> [{quoted}](name=rujitra,realm=NA,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=eAal50nw,comment-id=000000000001000000000000,timestamp=2019-11-05T23:19:33.841+0000)
>
> The comment was about the actions - I did not call the person abnormal.

Okay, so if I say "A normal person would give themselves a username that isn't rujitra" that is in no way a comment on you, only your actions?

> It seems you and The Djinn are being clouded by your own bias against the OP of that thread...

I haven't even seen the thread in question, and you're seriously gonna act like I'm trying to project my own opinion of the OP onto your comment?

C'mon dude.

> I never said the person was abnormal.

It is implied. When you posit that "normal people would do x instead", you're marking the OP as someone who isn't normal.

And the solution to that problem is simple: Don't make statements that openly imply the person is abnormal.

> I think this removal is a result of trying to find a problem where one does not exist by putting the obviously unintended and very thinly reasonable meaning into the words.

You're welcome to hold that opinion. I disagree.

> Furthermore, the OP may not have caused the other player’s **actions**, but they did cause the situation.

But by doing exactly what you accused *them* of -- they played the game in a way that they felt is best, and their Vayne got mad at them for that decision. Sure, the OP was frustrated that the Vayne wasn't more open to the hard-push playstyle, but that's not the OP's fault, nor is either the OP *or* the Vayne required to change their playstyle.

>... then the PB boards will simply become a place where players fear telling people the truth and the reality because “oh no, telling them they’re wrong is an insult”.

You can get the full point across without the insulting behavior:

>"Hey there. I get why you were frustrated, but it looks like you jumped right to frustration instead of trying to find a compromise. Remember that you don't get to dictate how any other players play, and they don't have to adapt to your preferences. As a result it's best to find a way to work with your team and seek a compromise if possible."

Yet before, when I would make a post like that and get into a long discussion, I was told that “long circular discussions” are not good boards behavior. Bluntness gets the point across much better, and no, bluntness is not rude.

> [{quoted}](name=rujitra,realm=NA,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=eAal50nw,comment-id=0000000000000000,timestamp=2019-11-05T21:08:09.462+0000)Yet before, when I would make a post like that and get into a long discussion, I was told that “long circular discussions” are not good boards behavior. Bluntness gets the point across much better, and no, bluntness is not rude.

1. You don't need to engage in an extended discussion after every post, and can simply drop a discussion that's becoming circular.
2. Simply put, your behavior in this post crossed the line between direct and rude. I appreciate that you disagree, but I believe this action was correctly taken and am giving you the best advice I can based on that assessment to prevent future such situations.

So if the goal of the board is to help people improve their behavior and understanding... yet being blunt is not allowed, and it’s suggested to just “drop” discussion, how does that fit together?

I am still very confused as you have simply said “I disagree” without actually responding to why you come to the conclusion you do - which isn’t providing any help in avoiding this in the future. I have laid out here my reasoning why the interpretation by the moderator is, while not necessarily **wrong**, is not the first conclusion that should be reached.

As one example, Julevi below responded to me with a comment that could very well be interpreted as rude or snarky. However, the interpretation I think most people would have is they simply were asking whether I had anything further to say to continue discussing. Just because something could be interpreted one way does not mean that is the most logical interpretation. If you feel that my comment was crossing a line, you should be able to both define how, and explain why my interpretation is less valid.

> [{quoted}](name=rujitra,realm=NA,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=eAal50nw,comment-id=000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2019-11-05T21:25:24.177+0000)So if the goal of the board is to help people improve their behavior and understanding... yet being blunt is not allowed, and it’s suggested to just “drop” discussion, how does that fit together?

As I've said, being direct and even bluntly direct is allowed. Being *insultingly* direct is not.

> I am still very confused as you have simply said “I disagree” without actually responding to why you come to the conclusion you do - which isn’t providing any help in avoiding this in the future.

I gave an example of a similar statement said without the offending portions. I've pointed out the specific portions I deem over the line.

>I have laid out here my reasoning why the interpretation by the moderator is, while not necessarily **wrong**, is not the first conclusion that should be reached.

What you see as a first conclusion *as the author* is not necessarily the first or only conclusion reached by a third party reader or the intended audience. We moderate based on our judgment, the rules, and how we interpret a comment will be likely to be read. As you said, the moderator is *not* necessarily wrong here, and that (in addition to my own agreement with said moderator's decision) is why I feel this was properly handled.

--------------------------------------

>Actually, I lost my specialist status because one of their “boards developers” who I’ve come to understand actually don’t have any developer ability literally laughed at me when I took a concern to them in the discord, then continued berating me for what he perceived to be an “immoral” statement I had made, until a herald (I don’t remember which one) came and broke it up.

This is inaccurate. While it is possible that event was a specific catalyst to the removal itself, that is definitely *not* the reason for the removal. I had voiced concerns to you previously and there had been behavioral patterns that I know were mentioned to you (because I mentioned them myself) that were a large part of the reason. I know I ultimately voted for your removal after being against it for some time *without considering* the incident you mention here and based solely on behavior elsewhere.

I won't deny that you did voice concerns.

That does not excuse the fact that I was literally laughed at, told I'm immoral in various ways, was accused of saying horrible things that I never had, and more by this "boards developer" who then unilaterally closed the room while I was still trying to discuss, and I didn't get so much as an apology (from anyone), much less any evidence that this person was ever reprimanded for their behavior towards me (especially given that they have made posts since then that suggest they still hold the same condescending, rude, and disruptive attitude they had with me in that chat).

I'll fully accept that this removal is not something you're willing to reverse, but when a "boards developer" is permitted to act that way towards me, I would assume I'd be able to act that way on the boards. If that's untrue, then it shows a clear favoritism given to people in the "inner circle".

On that note, I will attempt to make clear that my blunt comments are not insults in the future.

> [{quoted}](name=rujitra,realm=NA,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=eAal50nw,comment-id=00000000000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2019-11-06T01:18:07.661+0000)That does not excuse the fact that I was literally laughed at, told I'm immoral in various ways, was accused of saying horrible things that I never had, and more by this "boards developer" who then unilaterally closed the room while I was still trying to discuss...

We do not habitually discuss the conversations we have with individuals outside of the conversations *with* said individuals, so I will not detail precisely what transpired as a result of the interaction. Suffice to say I have reread the final pullroom you were involved in, and was previously aware of it.

If you remember the channel said accusations occurred in please let me know, as it was not in the final conversation the individual had with you (although the room closing is something I see here).

>I'll fully accept that this removal is not something you're willing to look at, but when a "boards developer" is permitted to act that way towards me, I would assume I'd be able to act that way on the boards. If that's untrue, then it shows a clear favoritism given to people in the "inner circle".

Behavior on Discord internal channels from Volunteer Staff is handled separately from behavior on the boards, because we do not issue time-based Discord warnings and instead handle things via internal conversations and, if appropriate, warnings/training. If you see on-boards behavior you are concerned about, feel free to report it.

It was in the conversation before the herald stepped in. The person was attempting to use leading questions to back me into "admitting" something that was both untrue and horrific to think that he would be accusing me of. I cannot remember the exact channel nor the exact conversation, as I was removed from the channel right as I was thinking to take screenshots of it.

As long as you're looking into it, there's obviously nothing more I can do, but I really don't like that you're suggesting that behavior in an official volunteer capacity on the official boards discord should be handled separately from the boards account. If you're not suggesting this exactly and I misinterpreted you I'm sorry, but in my (admittedly biased) opinion, the behavior demonstrated towards me in that communication is something that would merit immediate removal from their capacity given how appalling it was how I was being talked to.

I'd love to have a transcript of the chat, but again, I was removed from the chatroom randomly and without warning so was unable to get any form of transcript/screenshots.

> [{quoted}](name=rujitra,realm=NA,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=eAal50nw,comment-id=0000000000000000000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2019-11-06T02:29:23.417+0000)It was in the conversation before the herald stepped in.

I reread the entire final conversation you had in the pullroom prior to your removal from the program. I did not see any statements that you were immoral or being accused of making statements other than those that were reasonable interpretations of what you wrote. I understand the perspective you were coming from, but it is the same issue as this thread -- a comment easily read as an insult. In this case the line: "if you spent your time focusing on not being a shitty player instead of flaming and then complaining about your bans," if I'm looking at the correct conversation.

>...but I really don't like that you're suggesting that behavior in an official volunteer capacity on the official boards discord should be handled separately from the boards account. 

I'm sorry you don't like that, but I'm afraid we don't do time-based bans from the volunteer team, and handling issues internally through warnings, training, and, where necessary, removal is the policy that we have deemed best for the program. Someone's standing in the volunteer program is separate from their board access, although on-board violations can result in internal measures being taken as well.

>...the behavior demonstrated towards me in that communication is something that would merit immediate removal from their capacity given how appalling it was how I was being talked to.

Having reread the conversation, I cannot agree. I can agree the handling was not what I would call ideal, but it doesn't come *close* to the grounds I would set for immediate removal.

I can only tell you that if the way I was talked to by this person is not grounds for immediate removal from the program (given that I have seen this person act this way towards people on the boards too), I'm not sure what would be. This person was in a position of authority and clearly was abusing it for their own personal entertainment - literally laughing at me at times during the conversation. That is an attitude that, in my experience and opinion, is inconsistent with any position of authority, and while people *do* improve over time, leaving someone in a position of authority after such a display in hopes that they can be "retrained" or similar is... well, really just makes me feel like nothing is being done at all. If I had a transcript of the conversation, I'd be more than happy to post it and see what the rest of the community thinks about it - but I don't, and I presume that is one reason why this is considered a "non issue" - because I will forever be the only one outside of the moderation team to be able to see the behavior this person displayed towards someone with a legitimate concern.

Given that I doubt I will be able in any way to get a transcript of that chat, and even if I was, I'm sure I'd be prohibited from posting it on the boards to show what happened, I'll just drop this. While I greatly respect you personally, the issue of that chat has and will likely continue to leave a very sour taste in my mouth about the boards team. I suppose you're all glad that the chat couldn't be posted, because regardless of the issue, I was talked to in a way that is absolutely no way to handle a concern from a user of the product someone moderates. Thanks for helping with the issues today. I appreciate it.

> [{quoted}](name=rujitra,realm=NA,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=eAal50nw,comment-id=000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2019-11-06T03:19:56.087+0000)I can only tell you that if the way I was talked to by this person is not grounds for immediate removal from the program [given that I have seen this person act this way towards people on the boards too], I'm not sure what would be.

NDA violations. Violating a zero-tolerance board rule. A few other similar things. Handling one pullroom in a less-than-ideal fashion doesn't come close to qualifying, and the moderator in question tends to meme a bit harder than most -- which we *are* allowed to do, as we are *not* professionals. As long as it doesn't cross the line it's perfectly fine. I simply step in sometimes when it becomes too frequent or too much.

>I suppose you're all glad that the chat couldn't be posted...

With all due respect, you never *asked* me to post it or provide it. I don't give two fucks whether or not it's posted. Here you go. For ease of use I've also italicized the bits where I feel the moderator stepped outside the lines of what I would personally recommend. There are three instances, and in all of them I believe the moderator stepped a bit outside the lines but not far enough to merit more than a reminder to be more professional in pullrooms.

>**Moderator:** Hello?
> 
>**rujitra:** hey.
>**rujitra:** so i got a comment removed for saying "shitty player" when it was just using the same term the OP used.
>**rujitra:** I can see how it's very blunt to turn the OP's argument against them but I'm not seeing how it really merits a removal given that sometimes that's the best way to explain to someone "you are what you eat".
> 
>**Moderator:** But we removed the OP
>**Moderator:** What if I told you that just because someone else said something doesn't make it okay for you to say it?
> 
>**rujitra:** I can see that, but I wouldn't expect it to have been a warning to me.
>**rujitra:** So, saying "the reason you are being matched with this sort of player is because you have displayed the same amount of skill as them" is not an acceptable thing to say?
> 
>**Moderator:** You called them a shitty player
>**Moderator:** Not sure why you think we'd allow personal attacks
>**Moderator:** "if you spent your time focusing on not being a shitty player instead of flaming and then complaining about your bans."
>**Moderator:** And once we resolve this matter, we can discuss another matter with you as well
> 
>**rujitra:** If they're using the phrase themselves, I don't see how that's a personal attack.
>**rujitra:** It's just putting the phrase "you are matched with what you are" and using their own words.
>**rujitra:** By that standard, telling people they're matched with their skill level is always a personal attack when they're complaining.
> 
>**Moderator:** Now, I'm not saying the following example is equivalent, and I well understand it's potentially false equivalence; however, the point isn't the example itself, and more of the method of getting there
>**Moderator:** If someone calls their team r%%%%%ed, you can't say, 'maybe you would get less r%%%%%ed teams if you spent more effort being less r%%%%%ed'
> 
>**rujitra:** I can see why that one's bad. but to me, that one is bad because the term being used is a derogatory term for someone with mental illness.
> 
>**Moderator:** It's an insult
>**Moderator:** Just substitute one insult for another
> 
>**rujitra:** To me, if the OP of a thread is willing to call their skill level "shitty", then I don't see why it's not okay for those replying to them to call it shitty.
>**rujitra:** Similar to how if someone posts their chat logs, it's acceptable to tell them their chat logs are inappropriate/toxic/etc.
>**rujitra:** The OP opened themselves up to calling their skill level shitty.
>**rujitra:** I guess my question is this - where is the line between telling someone their skill is the same they're complaining about being okay, and it not?
> 
>**Moderator:** we don't allow for skill/rank shaming either, I believe
> 
>**rujitra:** So if someone says "why is matchmaking so shit i'm so much better than my team", you cannot explain to them that if they want to be matched with better players, they need to display better skill.
> 
>**Moderator:** So you should be able to call people shitty players?
>**Moderator:** *nice meme*
> 
>**rujitra:** I'm not meming at all.
>**rujitra:** I don't think you're understanding what I'm asking.
>**rujitra:** In what way do you acceptably tell someone that the reason they are matched with players is because they are the same skill as those players?
> 
>**Moderator:** Did you call them a shitty player?
> 
>**rujitra:** They called themselves a shitty player.
> 
>**Moderator:** and then
>**Moderator:** did you?
>**Moderator:** simple yes or no will do
> 
>**rujitra:** So, the context is unimportant and you're not willing to take the thread itself into consideration is what I'm gathering.
> 
>**Moderator:** *Lol*
> 
>**rujitra:** It doesn't matter if the OP called themselves a shitty player - pointing it out gets my comment removed and a warning.
> 
>**Moderator:** When has context ever been appropriate when determining whether insults should be acceptable?
> 
>**rujitra:** It's not an insult if they call themselves it first.
> 
>**Moderator:** *That's not how english works*
> 
>**rujitra:** It is, in fact.
>**rujitra:** Something is insulting or not based on the context it's used in.
> 
>**The Djinn:** Hey rujitra. Popping in for a moment.
>**The Djinn:** "So if someone says "why is matchmaking so shit i'm so much better than my team", you cannot explain to them that if they want to be matched with better players, they need to display better skill."
>**The Djinn:** I wanted to address this.
>**The Djinn:** You can absolutely explain this. But, importantly, you can do this without telling someone they're playing like shit (even if they said it first) and without accusing them of flaming and complaining (even if they are).
>
>**rujitra:** But is it violating a rule to be blunt?
>
>**The Djinn:** Most people who come to Player Behavior after a ban or chat restriction are frustrated, angry or upset. It is important that our responses remain positive and come from a genuine desire to help them understand what happened and why. Replies that are overly negative, dismissive or combative are not appropriate and may be removed.
>**The Djinn:** So yes, actually, it can be.
> 
>**rujitra:** If I'm remembering right (the comment wasn't linked), that was on GD.
>**rujitra:** If it was on PB then I can accept that yes it was overly combative based on those guidelines.
>**rujitra:** And I try to not comment like that on PB - only when there's a ranty post in GD where such a reply is the same "combativness" as the OP
> 
>**The Djinn:** Ah, it was on GD. But still:
>**The Djinn:** "Always be respectful to players, community members, moderators, and Rioters."
>**The Djinn:** When you choose to participate in a discussion with the rest of the playerbase, always try to be respectful and receptive to another player's point of view. Also, be mindful of how you present your point of view.
>**The Djinn:** "Don’t shy away from your feelings, but be straightforward, specific, and respectful when sharing them."
>**The Djinn:** "Criticism is an important and useful method of feedback, but must be respectful and constructive in nature."
>**The Djinn:** Being overly blunt can be a violation of all of the above.
>**The Djinn:** And you have a recurring habit of combativeness.
> 
>**rujitra:** I disagree that it was overly blunt for the thread and board it was in. But if that's the decision then I'm really not willing to attempt to argue for it.
> 
>**The Djinn:** You're allowed to disagree, certainly.
>
>**rujitra:** If it's not going to be re-considered then I'll just accept that and avoid those sorts of threads probably - because I don't like getting into long discussions because people don't understand the matchmaking, and a blunt comment seems to be the only way to avoid many of them.
>**rujitra:** Thank you for explaining it to me.
> 
>**Moderator:** That being said, given a lot of discussion and thought, we thought it would be best for both the program and you that we go forward with your separation from the specialist program.
> 
>**rujitra:** That's fine. I've never asked for the tag or for any special things. If you guys really think that, then by all means.
>**rujitra:** I disagree with the application of the rules on some of my comments, and as such I can see how it would be better to not give me a special tag.
>**rujitra:** I would like to ask someone to do something about Nubrac posting though while I'm still in this room as I suspect I'll be ceremoniously kicked from this when the conversation's over.

That's the full transcript. The only edit made was removing the name of the moderator in question and changing the quoted text to be *in* quotes as the Discord format doesn't translate well here.

To be honest I am quite surprised that you complain about your post being removed considering that a few of your comments still stand or parts of it are not removed by moderations where you showed an entitled attitude and/or "bluntness" - basically rudeness. You demand a lot for other people here on boards but then make a fuss when the moderation team decides to take actions against you?
Bluntness is not “basically rudeness”. Period.

> [{quoted}](name=rujitra,realm=NA,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=eAal50nw,comment-id=00010000,timestamp=2019-11-05T20:22:23.226+0000)
>
> Bluntness is not “basically rudeness”. Period.

The question you have to ask yourself is, what is your purpose here?  Are you trying to inform the OP, or are you trying to put down the OP?  If it's the latter, then yes, bluntness is basically rudeness.  If it's the former, then is the way you're conveying yourself the most effective way to do so?  Is your audience more likely to be receptive to your opinion, more likely to engage in a dialog, or even a meaningful debate,  if you convey your opinion politely, or if you're blunt and offputting?

When someone is like this OP and refuses to listen to anyone, then no, coddling them by being rainbows and using buzzwords like “unfortunately” and “maybe” and “slightly” and trying to dance around the issue does not work.

If someone gets frustrated by being told they are wrong or being told their behavior is a problem, that is a sign they did not want to discuss anyway. However, them getting frustrated is by default a sign that they are considering the topic - because if they weren’t considering that they were wrong, they have no reason to be frustrated.

So on one hand it works and they discuss, on the other hand they get frustrated because they are considering that it may be true. Win win.
In this entire thread you are refusing to listen to anyone as well. Its behavior like this that lost you your specialist title. So your behavior here is the problem.

Actually, I lost my specialist status because one of their “boards developers” who I’ve come to understand actually don’t have any developer ability literally laughed at me when I took a concern to them in the discord, then continued berating me for what he perceived to be an “immoral” statement I had made, until a herald (I don’t remember which one) came and broke it up.

This person is still a boards developer, I have never gotten an apology for the way he treated me in that chat, and when I asked for one was when the board developer unilaterally removed me from the room while I was still discussing with another person.

Sure that’s the reason. And yet we constantly see behavior like this unfitting of a specialist, and you refuse to change. You’ve refused to actually have any discussion because you cannot see yourself being wrong.

> [{quoted}](name=rujitra,realm=NA,application-id=6heBIhQc,discussion-id=eAal50nw,comment-id=00010000,timestamp=2019-11-05T20:22:23.226+0000)
>
> Bluntness is not “basically rudeness”. Period.

Got nothing else to say?

Try to avoid talking about the person themselves and focus on what they did. Also avoid phrasing that could be taken the wrong way.

> You caused this.

"Your actions caused this." The practical difference is basically nil, but now we're talking about what they did, not about the person per se.

> Instead of doing what a normal person would do and trying to discuss a compromise, you tried to make everyone else do your way or the highway.

"Instead of doing something constructive and helpful and trying to discuss a compromise, you tried to unilaterally mandate your teammates' actions." The most direct antonym of "normal" is "abnormal," which isn't generally seen as a positive trait. Many other similar words don't have this problem, like ordinary/extraordinary, usual/unusual, common/uncommon, and so on. Strange but true. The phrase "your way or the highway" also has negative connotations, so describing the same effect with more neutral language helps you fly under the radar.

> People like you who think they know everything and that their teammates must listen to them and think the same way... you’re right, those are the problem with the League community.

"Disagreement on strategy and refusal to compromise are indeed significant issues in the League community." We're staying far, far away from "people like you," especially when it's followed later in the sentence by "the problem with the League community." I realize my suggested sentence here sounds like vapid corporate nonsense, but it conveys the intended message without being rude.

 

When creating my pre-written answers to common PB questions ("T1 was unbanned," "permas are theft," "I didn't start it," etc.), I found that it's much easier to be polite and neutral when you're not actually talking to a particular person. I wrote those answers purely in response to ideas. That way, instead of seeing "all I did was call my teammates %%%%%%% and %%  %% %%%%% and i h8 u all" and having a dialog with that person about how that's an awful thing to say, I was simply expounding on where LoL's rules come from. Additionally, having pre-written responses allows for a lot more editing time, where I can tweak and revise and soften where needed. Basically, when you respond to someone, don't respond _to_ **them**. Use their post as a sort of essay prompt, and write your post as if you're talking to an arbitrary reader.
